ygData.subject: Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Jeff, ... Here are some good papers on the subject. Some are more focused on inference in biology, but it applies just as well for our research.

Hey Jeff,

> I believe it is incorrect to just show standard error as you h=
ave done and not report a p-value, a lesson I learned at MSU from Lenski, O=
fria, and others. Oftentimes something looks significant on a plot with var=
iance, especially if you use such a generous variance indicator as standard=
 error. What would be the harm in also including a p-value in addition to y=
our visualization of the data and variance? Do you have any modern stats ar=
ticles that argue in favor of this practice? I am asking because as a revie=
wer I would complain if I saw this practice, and if I am incorrectly compla=
ining I'd like to know so I do not make unjustified requests/complaints in =
my reviews. I do know that some statisticians do advocate not using p-value=
s, but I wasn't under the impression that the alternative was simply to rem=
ove a p-value and leave in an typical plot with average+/- some indication =
of variance. I assumed that there was something else, more complicated, tha=
t they would substitute in place of the p-value. 

Here are some good paper=
s on the subject. Some are more focused on inference in biology, but it app=
lies just as well for our research.

http://warnercnr.colostate.edu/~anders=
on/PDF_files/TESTING.pdf

http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/=
S0378112703003311

http://www.jstor.org/stable/3803089

http://www.ncbi.nlm=
.nih.gov/pubmed/17944619

http://beheco.oxfordjournals.org/content/20/6/136=
3.abstract
